awd_titl_txt: ERI: Harnessing Probabilistic Deep Learning Method Integrated with Tailored Features for Enhanced Real-Time Machinery Fault Diagnosis and Prognosis
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This Engineering Research Initiation (ERI) grant will fund research that enables real-time quality control and accurate decision making in the operation of complex machinery, including critical components in modern manufacturing, thereby promoting the progress of science and advancing the national prosperity. Fault diagnosis and prognosis for machinery systems play an indispensable role in ensuring integrity, safety, and performance. Due to many sources of uncertainty, reliable real-time fault monitoring and prediction are beyond current capabilities. Machine learning-based techniques show promise in overcoming the limitations of traditional measurement approaches, but state-of-the-art tools lack the ability to identify faults that were not encountered during training on previously collected data. This project will overcome these limitations by creating a new machine-learning framework that uses probabilistic ideas to account for measurement uncertainty, is sensitive to time-varying fault signatures, and trains continuously on real-time data. The new framework will enable substantial performance enhancements in reliability, efficiency, practicality, and robustness of machinery fault diagnosis and prognosis in aerospace, transportation, and infrastructure industries. Related software tools and curated datasets will be shared publicly in order to promote technology transfer and broad access to the research methodology. Undergraduate research opportunities will provide hands-on learning experiences and, leveraging a partnership between Michigan Tech University and three Michigan community colleges, help broaden participation in STEM of students from currently underrepresented groups and the institutions that serve them.

This research aims to make fundamental contributions to the integration of several deep-learning technologies with an algorithm for optimized sensor placement to enable the use of real-time vibration measurements for detection and prediction of machinery faults also outside of those in a given training data set, robustly to measurement noise and time-varying operating conditions, and reliably even given limited data. It will achieve this outcome by relying on a Bayesian convolutional neural network architecture that builds a probabilistic model for feature detection, a long short-term memory architecture that is sensitive to intrinsic temporal correlations characteristic of the progressive nature of faults, and a variational inference-based backpropagation optimization algorithm for real-time model updating, further facilitating generalizations to previously unseen faults. This project will use the Shapley Additive Explanations approach to quantify the importance of signal features for fault detection, and will apply this metric to optimize sensor placement for an experimental gearbox that will be used to test and validate the algorithmic framework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fault diagnosis and prognosis plays an important role in machinery systems to ensure their reliability, safety, and performance. Significant research efforts have been made to develop intelligent, effective, and robust fault diagnosis and prognosis techniques to help forecast residual life, enable predictive and proactive maintenance, reduce productivity loss, and ultimately avoid major system breakdowns and catastrophes of mechanical systems. However, the state-of-the-art fault monitoring and prediction methods lack promising and reliable performance in practice due to various sources of uncertainty. In this research, our project goal is to develop a new machine-learning framework to address these challenges such that the framework is robust to measurement noise, time-varying operating conditions, limited datasets, and machinery faults that fall outside of those in the given training data.

During the course of this project, many such techniques have been successfully developed. For instance, several new semi-supervised deep learning methods were developed that allow the integration of rich and inexpensive unlabeled data into the fault diagnosis framework to achieve accurate and robust fault detection (even for unseen faults that are beyond the training dataset) without requiring a large amount of labeled data, which is typically limited in practice. Furthermore, many rolling bearings are installed in complex machinery systems, making it impractical to assume a known location of failure. Accordingly, a novel hierarchical transfer learning method was developed in this project to identify the fault location and condition at the same time. As far as uncertainties are concerned (such as time-varying conditions and measurement noise), probabilistic approaches (e.g., convolutional neural networks with Bayesian optimization) were developed to enhance the efficiency and robustness of fault diagnosis.

In addition to the development of fault diagnosis techniques, new prognosis methods were also proposed in this research to improve the accuracy of remaining useful life prediction. The main contribution is the introduction of human knowledge/physics to conventional data-driven methods, thereby improving the physical interpretation of the entire prognosis process and ultimately leading to enhanced accuracy. Moreover, a laboratory-scale gear system is also established in this project. Unique experimental data is collected under varied operational conditions, fault types and severities, and sensor locations. This dataset is used to validate the developed algorithms and is made publicly available for researchers in the community to validate other techniques.

The developed algorithms and models of this work are expected to advance the state-of-the-art in the area of fault diagnosis and prognosis. The research findings are summarized in multiple publications, both in peer-reviewed journals and conferences. Since the developed structural health monitoring methods are generic, they can impact a broad range of disciplines such as civil and aerospace structures, manufacturing processes, and marine infrastructures. Particularly, the algorithms developed in this project were extended to the fault diagnosis of offshore mooring systems (e.g., of wave energy converters, floating offshore wind platforms, etc.), which have a strong need for such techniques given the significant consequences of mooring failure. Several algorithms (e.g., domain adaptation techniques) were developed that addressed the unique challenge of offshore infrastructures, namely the highly random system responses due to the dynamic ocean environment. Furthermore, a laboratory-scale floating offshore wind testing platform was established in this project. Unique testing data is collected to validate the developed algorithms and is made publicly available.

Finally, this project provided advanced research experience to multiple doctoral and master’s students, including training in data analytics, deep learning, and dynamics. It is noted that one Ph.D. student also successfully defended his doctoral dissertation leveraging the work produced in this project. Moreover, this project offered undergraduate students unique lab tour opportunities and provided real-world examples in teaching materials. In total, this project made a positive impact on human resources as well as the teaching experience.
